video.title: Selenium Course for Beginners - Web Scraping Bots, Browser Automation, Testing (Tutorial)
video.description:
Learn Selenium by building a web scraping bot in Python. Selenium is a powerful web automation tool that can be used for browser automation, to test front-end code, and create web scraping bots. 

💻 Code: https://github.com/jimdevops19/SeleniumSeries

✏️ Course developed by JimShapedCoding. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCU8d7rcShA7MGuDyYH1aWGg

⭐️ Additional resources ⭐️
🔗 Python Download: https://www.python.org/downloads
🔗 Pycharm Download: https://www.jetbrains.com/pycharm/download 
🔗 Selenium Documentation: https://selenium-python.readthedocs.io/ 
🔗 Copied and Pasted during the video:
   ‣ https://www.seleniumeasy.com/test/jquery-download-progress-bar-demo.html (Section 1&2)
   ‣ https://www.seleniumeasy.com/test/basic-first-form-demo.html (Section 3)
🔗 Chromedriver download website: https://chromedriver.storage.googleapis.com/index.html
🔗 All the Explicit waits: https://selenium-python.readthedocs.io/waits.html
🔗 My Personal website for code snippets: http://jimshapedcoding.com

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Getting Started with the basics 
⌨️ (0:16:44) Explicit vs Implicit
⌨️ (0:28:11) Sending Keys & CSS Selector
⌨️ (0:43:42) Structure a Bot Project
⌨️ (1:03:13) Deal Searching
⌨️ (1:44:38) Booking Filtrations
⌨️ (2:07:24) Execution from a CLI
⌨️ (2:21:31) Deal Reporting

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Wong Voon jinq
👾 hexploitation
👾 Katia Moran
👾 BlckPhantom
👾 Nick Raker
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster
👾 AppWrite

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Snowy Bear
topLevelComment.text: I used to work for an online flight ticket website. It's not that easy. I still have the programs I wrote to scan competitors websites for prices. The object IDs change every time you bring up the website. You can't identify objects by ID, you have to do it another way, xpath by text is usually the best way but not all objects have text. And I hate Python. Give me Groovy all day long.

topLevelComment.author: Akira Blac
topLevelComment.text:
use this for browser to not  automatically closing:
`
options = webdriver.ChromeOptions()
options.add_experimental_option("detach", True)
options.add_experimental_option('excludeSwitches', ['enable-logging'])
driver = webdriver.Chrome(options=options)
`

topLevelComment.author: Disasterdon
topLevelComment.text:
For folks who want to automate dates in different moth ( 01:26:30 ), you can simply add inside that method a  

self.implicitly_wait(0) #we set the wait time to 0 so actually can determine if the date is present in the code, otherwise, we will be stuck because selenium will w8 for the element to show

while len (self.find_elements(By.CSS_SELECTOR, f'td[data-date="{check_in_date}"]')) ==0:  #we gonna use find_elemets and measure length of that, so if we find an element length will be 1, but since we use while loop we can get stuck inside if you throw some date that is not in the table
       next_month = self.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, '.bui-calendar__control.bui-calendar__control--next') #select a next moth
       next_month.click() 

self.implicitly_wait(5) #for safty we turn back our wait time

 maybe needs some adjustments if the difference between the check-in date and the check-out date is bigger than one month but i just wanted to show you a solution, you can work around that for your cases.

for those who don't know, 
the newer version of selenium has removed the driver.find_element_by_id and similar functions, the new way of writing the same is-
driver.find_element("id" , "<name of id>")

hope that helps

topLevelComment.author: Butters
topLevelComment.text:
Was getting 'chromedriver' executable needs to be in PATH despite following along with the recommendations and I figured out the issue for both Mac and Win.

First, I added a print statement right after the os.environ path setting piece:
print(os.environ['PATH'])

I noticed it was missing a ; in Windows (: in Mac). So, I modified driver_path append step to this and it worked:
os.environ['PATH'] += os.pathsep + self.driver_path

os.pathsep adds your OS specific path separator character.

replies.author: DJ - JD
replies.text:
I had the same issue but used a different approach. I gave my directory for the selenium driver explicitly when defining the __init__ method and put it in the driver_path parameter. This would look like: 

def __init__(self,  driver_path = "C:/your/location/here/chromedriver.exe", teardown=False): 

Then, I passed driver_path into __init__ when calling super(). This would look like: 

super(Booking, self).__init__(driver_path)

This way you don't need to use the os package.

replies.author: frag782
replies.text:
Windows Path variable is a single string of semi-colon separated paths to various executables, which should look something like: "Path1;Path2;...;PathN".
A good practice is to add a semi-colon after any new path you add to Path.

topLevelComment.author: Vaibhav
topLevelComment.text: 9:15 - r as the prefix to a string indicates a "raw string"; that is, character sequences like \n will be treated as literals and not as escaped control characters (as they normally are in a string.) It's useful when you expect your string to include backslashes, for instance Windows paths, or certain regex expressions.

topLevelComment.author: Kevin Wesah
topLevelComment.text: my ultimate goal is to get into cyber security ( you know ethical hacking and pentesting stuff) kindly advice the core languages i should first  focus on  . i am currently learning C then move on to python...do i need c++ and  java as well?. i was planning after python i go deep into html css and javascript and php to understand how websites are built also. so i'm confused if i will need java and c++ for cyber security .advice so that i dont spend so much time learning them/ thanks

replies.author: Truth Matters
replies.text:
Python is a good language to learn, because many hacking/pentesting tools are written in python. Cybersecurity is incredibly broad though, so you can find a use for most any language that you learn. If you want to have a good broad foundation you will need: 

- Javascript for anything web related 
- SQL for SQL injection
- Python to understand hacking tools and write your own quickly and easily, also it is helpful to understand dynamic / interpreted programming languages.
- C to understand low level programming concepts and compilers

Where you go from there is gonna depend on where your area of interest lies. Recently, more and more malware seems to use 'exotic' programming languages like D or Nim in an effort to avoid detection by AV software, so perhaps learning those will be helpful if you want to research those types of malware. If you wanna focus on Mac and iOS security, you need objectiveC and Swift. Those are just some examples. 

C++ and Java could also be useful, but the most important thing is that you get a good grasp of both (systems) programming and scripting. If you really understand that in one language, then other languages will be easy enough to pick up on an as needs basis. I recommend Harvard's CS50 if you are completely new to programming. It covers C, Python, SQL, Javascript, HTML.

topLevelComment.author: john kim
topLevelComment.text: Do you have selenium with java?

replies.author: Truth Matters
replies.text:
Yes, most languages can use selenium, as the protocol to communicate with the webdriver uses JSON, so it's relatively easy to implement a Selenium library for any given language. Officially Selenium supports:
- python
- Java
- Javascript
- Ruby
- C# (the dotnet ecosystem)

There are also libraries for other languages such as Dart (webdriver, maintained by google), but those are not officially maintained by SeleniumHQ
